case_name: Income Tax Officer v. Nawab Sahib Mir Osman Alikhan Bahadur, H. E. H., the Nizam of Hyderabad

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1179-1782 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeals from Judgment Order dated 7th March 1969 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition Nos. 1042-1045 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment Order dated the 7th March, 1969 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition Nos. 1042-1045 of 1964. C. Manchanda, B.

facts.text: High Court directed Income Tax Officer to refrain from proceeding against respondent under sec. 147(a) of Income Tax Act 1961.

anchor.surface_text: High Court of Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad by which the High Court directed the appellant, Income Tax Officer, Income Tax-cum-Wealth Tax Circle 11, Hydera

facts.text: ITO served notices under sec. 148 IT Act 1961 on respondent Nawab Sahib Mir Osman Ali Khan Bahadur, Nizam of Hyderabad for assessment years 1955-56 to 1958-59.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had served on the respondent, Nawab Sahib Mir Osman Alikhan Bahadur, H. E. H., the Nizam of Hyderabad, notices under sec. 148 of the income

facts.text: Assessments for AY 1955-56, 1956-57, 1957-58, 1958-59 completed on March 18 1958, March 19 1958, July 20 1958, March 28 1961 under IT Act 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Assessments for the aforesaid four years were completed respectively on March 18, 1958, March 19, 1958, July 20, 1958 and March 28, 1961 under the income Tax

facts.text: ITO queried respondent about rites and ceremonies of marriages with four ladies: Dulhan Pasha Begum Saheba, Mazharunnisa Begumsaheba, Laila Begum Saheba, Jani Begum Saheba.

anchor.surface_text: After the returns in respect of the said years were filed, the Income Tax Officer called upon the respondent to state his relationship with four ladies by putting

facts.text: Respondent executed three trust deeds on May 1 1950 (Family Trust), August 6 1950 (Miscellaneous Trust), December 29 1950 (Family Pocket Money Trust) for benefit of Mazharunnisa Begum, Laila Begum, Jani Begum and their minor children.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on May 1, 1950, August 6, 1950 and December 29, 1950 the respondent had executed three trust deeds, described respectively as Family Trust,

facts.text: In trust deeds of 1950, three ladies described as wives of respondent, father of their minor children; in one as 'ladies of position'.

anchor.surface_text: in the aforesaid trust deeds the three ladies were described as wives of the respondent who was also referred to as the father of their minor children. In one

facts.text: Trust deeds of 1950 were before ITO before completing assessments for four years. No dispute.

anchor.surface_text: There is no dispute that these trust deeds were before the Income Tax Officer before he completed the assessments for the said four years.

facts.text: On September 9 1957, C.B. Taraporewala, Financial Adviser of respondent, filed statement: only Dulhan Pasha legally wedded wife, other three not married validly under Muslim law, called wives due to position, children not legitimate.

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1957 Shri C. B. Taraporewala, Financial Adviser and General Power of Attorney Agent of the respondent, filed a statement before the Income Tax

facts.text: ITO accepted explanation and did not include income of three ladies and children from trusts in respondent's total income for four years under sec 16(3) IT Act 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This explanation apparently satisfied the income Tax officer because in assessing the total income of the respondent for the said four years he did not include

facts.text: Beneficiaries of trusts separately assessed on trust income along with individual income. Admitted.

anchor.surface_text: It is also admitted that the beneficiaries of the trusts were separately assessed on the income derived from the trusts along with their individual income.

facts.text: Notices under sec 148 issued on March 13 1964 to reopen assessments under sec 147.

anchor.surface_text: On March 13, 1964 the notices under sec. 148 of the Income Tax Act, 1961 were issued seeking to reopen the assessments under sec. 147 of the Act.

facts.text: Authorized representatives filed supplemental returns for four years without prejudice, affirming original returns.

anchor.surface_text: After some correspondence with the income Tax Officer, the authorized representatives of the respondent, M s. S. G. Dastgir and Company, Chartered Accountants,

facts.text: ITO letter dated April 15 1964 stated reasons for reopening: Fern Hill Trust March 21 1957 and Race View Trust December 5 1957 not brought to notice earlier.

anchor.surface_text: By his letter dated April 15, 1964 addressed to M s. Dastgir and Company, the Income Tax officer stated the reasons for reopening the assessments under sec.

facts.text: Fern Hill Trust created March 21 1957 for children of Laila Begum, describing her as wife and children as respondent's.

anchor.surface_text: Referring to two subsequent trusts named Fern Hill and Race View created by the respondent on March 21,1957 and December 5, 1957 respectively, it was stated

facts.text: Race View Trust created December 5 1957 for Jani Begum and son Imdad Jah Bahadur, describing them as wife and son of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Fern Hill Trust was created for the benfit of the children of Laila Begum and Race View Trust for the benefit of Jani Begum and her son Imdad Jah Bahadur.

facts.text: Fern Hill and Race View Trust Deeds of 1957 not produced before ITO during original assessments. Admitted.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly Fern Hill and Race View Trust Deeds executed in 1957 were not produced before the Income Tax officer when he made the original assessments for

facts.text: High Court allowed four writ petitions, prevented ITO from proceeding under sec 147.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent challenged the validity of the proceedings under sec. 147 sought to be initiated by filing four writ petitions in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Supreme Court holds ITO had no valid reasons to believe omission to disclose material facts, no jurisdiction under sec 147(a).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was right in holding that the Income Tax officer had no valid reasons to believe that the respondent had omitted or failed to disclose fully and

facts.text: Trust deeds of 1957 conform to those of 1950, repeat same descriptions, non-production not non-disclosure of material fact.

anchor.surface_text: The documents of 1957 conform to those of 1950 in material particulars the trust deeds of 1957 only repeat what the deeds of 1950 had disclosed. Non-productio

facts.text: ITO's second thoughts on same material do not warrant sec 147 proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Having second thoughts on the same material does not warrant the initiation of a proceeding under sec. 147 of the Income Tax Act, 1961.

facts.text: Court not deciding whether ladies were legally wedded wives of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, we are not called upon in this proceeding to record a finding on the question whether in fact the ladies were respondents legally wedded wives.

facts.text: Status of three ladies as wives disputed: respondent claims not legally wedded, only position; ITO claims presumption under sec 268 Mulla's Mohammedan Law.

concepts.interpretation: ITO lacks jurisdiction to reopen as no omission or failure to disclose material facts; 1957 deeds repeat 1950 disclosures already considered.

concepts.unlisted_description: Permits reassessment if ITO has reason to believe income escaped due to assessee's omission to fully disclose material facts.

anchor.surface_text: Clause a of Sec. 147 of the Income Tax Act, 1961 under which the assessments were sought to be reopened, so far as it is relevant for the present purpose, provides that if the Income Tax Officer has reason to believe that, by reason of the omission or failure on the part of an assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment

concepts.unlisted_description: Permits reassessment if ITO has reason to believe income escaped due to assessee's omission to fully disclose material facts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was right in holding that the Income Tax officer had no valid reasons to believe that the respondent had omitted or failed to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment and consequently had no jurisdiction to reopen the assessments for the four years in question.

concepts.interpretation: No valid reason to believe non-disclosure where facts already known; ITO's conclusion on same material lacks jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Under sec. 16 3 of the income Tax Act of 1922, in computing the total income of any individual for the purposes of assessment, the income of the wife or minor child of the assessee arising from assets transferred by the husband to the wife or the minor child otherwise than for adequate consideration was to be included.

holdings.text: The Income Tax Officer had no valid reasons to believe that the respondent had omitted or failed to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment and consequently had no jurisdiction to reopen the assessments for the four years in question.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was right in holding that the Income Tax officer had no valid reasons to believe that the respondent had omitted or failed to disclose fully and

holdings.reasoning_summary: All material facts from 1950 trust deeds and financial adviser's explanation were before ITO during original assessments; 1957 deeds repeat same descriptions without new information.

holdings.text: Non-production of the documents executed in 1957 at the time of the original assessments cannot therefore be regarded as non-disclosure of any material fact necessary for the assessment of the respondent for the relevant assessment years.

anchor.surface_text: The documents of 1957 conform to those of 1950 in material particulars the trust deeds of 1957 only repeat what the deeds of 1950 had disclosed. Non-productio

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1957 trust deeds conform to and repeat descriptions in 1950 deeds already disclosed and considered by ITO.

holdings.text: Having second thoughts on the same material does not warrant the initiation of a proceeding under sec. 147 of the Income Tax Act, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Having second thoughts on the same material does not warrant the initiation of a proceeding under sec. 147 of the Income Tax Act, 1961.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ITO accepted explanation earlier based on same facts; reopening based on reconsideration without fresh facts lacks jurisdiction under sec. 147(a).

holdings.text: The law has not changed since the original assessments were made and it was open to the Income Tax Officer to make that presumption at the time. If he should have but did not do so then, he cannot avail of sec. 147 to correct that mistake.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Manchanda, learned counsel for the appellant, took us through several sections of Mullas Principles of Mohammedan Law including sec. 268 and submitted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if presumption of marriage under sec. 268 Mulla applicable, ITO could have applied it earlier; sec. 147 not for correcting errors of judgment on same material.

holdings.text: We are not called upon in this proceeding to record a finding on the question whether in fact the ladies were respondent's legally wedded wives.

anchor.surface_text: In any event, we are not called upon in this proceeding to record a finding on the question whether in fact the ladies were respondents legally wedded wives.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceeding concerns only jurisdictional condition under sec. 147, not merits of marital status.

holdings.text: The High Court exercising jurisdiction under Art. 226 had power to investigate whether on the material before him the Income-Tax Officer was justified in proceeding under sec. 147.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court examined absence of fresh material, not sufficiency or correctness of ITO's conclusion from existing material; investigates jurisdictional fact of reason to believe.

holdings.text: In this case, the decision of the High Court is not that the material before the Income Tax Officer was insufficient or that he had failed to draw the correct conclusion from the material before him but that no fresh material had come to light justifying reopening of the assessments.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes cases where HC probes merits vs. jurisdictional precondition of fresh facts for sec. 147.
